description.narrative:
Insatsen syftar till att stödja ILC (Initiative pour un leadership cohesif) i deras arbete med att skapa förutsättningar för fredsdialog och konfliktlösning/medling. ILC är en fransk-registrerad icke-statlig organisation med lång erfarenhet i DR Kongo inom området dialog och medling. ILCs metodologi bygger på att en fredlig lösning till konflikterna i DRK endast kan komma från kongoleserna själva.
Genom att anordna återkommande sammankomster under flertalet dagar med inflytelserika kongolesiska aktörer på alla nivåer / från olika samhällsskick/ etniska grupper, arbetar ILC med att deltagarna ska granska eller fördjupa sin förståelse kring de viktigaste drivkrafterna för landets / provinsens kriser. Vidare är ambitionen att deltagarna ska granska eller nyansera sin övertygelse om att de inte är intressenter i de kriser som råder i landet (utökat ansvarstagande), samt granska sin övertygelse om att det är upp till externa aktörer (internationella samfundet, grannländerna etc.) att lösa problemen.
Ambassaden stödjer insatsen med 2 000 000 SEK under 2017-2019 och utgör tillsammans med Storbritannien och Schweiz givargruppen. Det svenska stödet är inte öronmärkt till vissa budgetutgifter i projektbudgeten utan utgör tillsammans med de andra givarnas bidrag stöd till projektet och organisationen.

The initiative aims to support ILC (Initiative pour un leadership cohesif) in their efforts to create peace and conflict resolution / mediation conditions. ILC is a French-registered non-governmental organization with long experience in DR Congo in the field of dialogue and mediation. The ILC methodology is based on the fact that a peaceful solution to the conflicts in DRC can only come from the Congolese themselves.
By organizing recurring gatherings for several days with influential Congolese actors at all levels / from different community / ethnic groups, ILC is working to allow participants to review or deepen their understanding of the key drivers of the country's / provinces' crises. Furthermore, the ambition is that participants should take increased responsibility for the conflicts and their solutions.
The Embassy supports the contribution with SEK 2 000 000 in 2017-2019 and, together with the United Kingdom and Switzerland, constitutes the donor group. Swedish support is not earmarked for certain budget expenditures in the project budget but, together with the contributions of the other donors, supports the project and the organization as such.
The project aims to increase goodwill and cohesive leadership amongst influential actors to address DRC's crises and find solutions to the violence through strong and stable political leadership.

description.narrative: Throughout the implementation period a number of results have been achieved. ILC has conducted a number of workshops. The two dialogue workshops organised in Murhesa, South Kivu delivered a declaration of commitment to engage in a process of disarmament, demobilization, reinsertion, reintegration and reconciliation. The declaration was signed by close to 50 representatives of armed groups, community members and government representatives. An important step in created a common understanding of how peace can be brought to South Kivu. The dialogues leading up to this declaration were built around an aim to ensure the triumph of a peaceful and community-based alternative to the military and bring together legitimate respondents of the armed groups and the state for a community and state reappropriation of peace in the East, through shared responsibility. A process of community demobilization, disarmament, reinsertion, reintegration and reconciliation must be launched in small steps and with national and local ownership of influential leaders. Cohesive leadership has been anchored in the territories among local leaders whom all for the most part want peaceful coexistence but are influenced from external forces. It is expected that the close ties created by the Murhesa process between formal and informal Congolese armed actors will lead to a common willingness to forge alliances with foreign groups. While the Murhesa dialogue processes where the key result of this intervention the successes that ILC have achieved in building trust between different actors resulted in a number of other spin off initiatives. For example, ILC received UNICEF funding to take a lead in dialogue between communities and leaders trying to increase acceptance for the Ebola response in the Butembo area in North Kivu marked by violence and attacks against health personnel. ILC was mentioned by one of the key political actors in "Grand Nord" as well as the Minister of Health to be the only organisation that can take on such a dialogue.
